[**Theorem**]{} Any topological space with the is connected.

[**Proof.**]{} We will prove the contrapositive. Suppose $X$ is a
topological space which is not connected. So there are non-empty
disjoint open sets $A,B\subseteq X$ such that $X=A\cup B$. Then there
are elements $a\in A$ and $b\in B$, and we can define a function
$f\colon X\to X$ by
$$f(x) = \left\{ \begin {array}{ll} a, & \mbox{when} \, x\in B, \\
 b, & \mbox{when} \, x\in A. \\
 \end{array} \right.$$ Since $A\cap B={\varnothing}$ and $A\cup B=X$,
the function $f$ is well-defined. Also, $a\notin B$ and $b\notin A$, so
$f$ has no fixed point. Furthermore, if $V$ is an open set in $X$, a
short calculation shows that $f^{-1}(V)$ is ${\varnothing}, A,B$ or $X$,
all of which are open sets. So $f$ is continuous, and therefore $X$ does
not have the fixed-point property. $\Box$

[9]{} G.J. Jameson, *Topology and Normed Spaces*, Chapman and Hall,
1974. L.E. Ward, *Topology, An Outline for a First Course*, Marcel
Dekker, Inc., 1972.
